TEG 6S System in Neonates and Premature Infants

Overview

The Thromboelastograph (TEG) 6S, developed by Haemonetics, is a point-of-care device used to assess blood coagulation in critical care settings like pediatric cardiac surgery and extracorporeal life support (ECLS). It uses citrated blood samples to prevent clotting, with clotting factors reactivated for analysis. This summary reviews its application in neonates (infants <1 month) and premature infants (born <37 weeks), based on five key studies and additional literature.

Key Findings

  • Neonates: TEG 6S is effective in neonates, providing reference intervals, predicting bleeding risks, and guiding therapy in cardiac surgery and ECLS.
  • Premature Infants: Limited TEG 6S-specific data, but general thromboelastography studies suggest balanced hemostasis, supporting potential use.
  • Blood Collection: Citrated blood samples are standard, with no reported issues related to citric acid or clotting factor reactivation.
  • Research Gaps: Further studies are needed to establish TEG 6S efficacy and reference intervals in premature infants.

Study Summaries

Moynihan 2021: Pediatric TEG 6S Reference Values

A prospective study of 254 children, including neonates, established age-specific TEG 6S reference intervals. Neonates showed distinct coagulation profiles. Citrated blood samples were used without issues. PubMed

Lindhardt 2022: TEG 6S in Cardiac Surgery

Retrospective study of 279 infants (median age 66 days) found TEG 6S predicts bleeding (>10 ml/kg) with 74% sensitivity. Citrated samples were reliable, but premature infants were not specified. PubMed

Magunia 2019: Heparin Reversal in Cardiac Surgery

Retrospective study of 40 children (median age 130 days) showed TEG 6S had limited correlation with conventional tests for heparin reversal. Citrated samples were effective. PubMed

Moynihan 2017: ECLS Coagulation Monitoring

Prospective/retrospective study in children on ECLS found TEG 6S correlated with heparin dose. Likely included neonates; citrated samples were used. PubMed

Benegni 2025: TEG 6S vs. TEG 5000

Prospective study of 30 children (median age 206 days) confirmed TEG 6S and TEG 5000 are interchangeable. Citrated samples were reliable. PubMed

Premature Infants

Direct TEG 6S studies in premature infants are scarce, but general thromboelastography studies (Sokou 2015, Motta 2017) suggest balanced hemostasis, indicating potential TEG 6S applicability. No issues with citrated samples were reported.

Detailed Report Preview

Download PDF

Conclusion

TEG 6S is effective in neonates for coagulation monitoring in critical care settings, with reliable citrated blood sampling. Limited data on premature infants suggest potential use, but further research is needed to establish specific guidelines.

Viscoelastic Coagulation Monitors in Neonatology: Focus on VCM

Client Inquiry Overview

This report addresses a $200 CDRH 510(k) database query for the Viscoelastic Coagulation Monitor (VCM) by Entegrion, focusing on neonates (<1 month) and premature infants (<37 weeks). It compares VCM with TEG and ROTEM, detailing FDA status, blood sampling, and clinical applications using 18 PubMed articles.

VCM by Entegrion

Regulatory Status

  • 510(k): K182208 (Mar 27, 2019, FDA)
  • Class: II (21 CFR 864.5425, JPA)
  • Adverse Events: None reported (MAUDE)
  • Neonatal Use: Supported by studies, not FDA-labeled

Blood Sampling

  • Type: Native blood (0.3 ml, heel prick)
  • Timing: Immediate testing, no citric acid
  • Reliability: High with standardized heel prick (ICC 0.289–0.879, Radicioni 2022)

VCM’s native blood approach simplifies testing, ideal for NICUs, but requires rapid analysis.

VCM Clinical Applications

  • Full-Term/Late-Preterm: Accelerated coagulation (CT: 5.3 min, CFT: 2.4 min, Alpha: 60.8°) in 45 neonates (Amelio 2022).
  • Premature Infants: Feasible, supported by balanced hemostasis (Sokou 2015), limited VCM-specific data.
  • Use Cases: NICU monitoring, sepsis, hemorrhage, potential cardiac surgery/ECMO (Cortesi 2022).

Comparison with TEG and ROTEM

Device Sample Volume Applications
VCM Native 0.3 ml NICU monitoring, sepsis
TEG Citrated 0.36–1 ml Cardiac, ECMO (Stevens 2025)
ROTEM Citrated 0.36–1 ml Sepsis, ECMO (Sokou 2024)

TEG and ROTEM have more neonatal data, while VCM offers simpler, portable testing.

Regulatory Timeline

TEG 6S Clinical Research Dashboard

Comprehensive analysis of neonatal & pediatric applications

Key Neonatal Research Findings

Critical Research Gap Identified

No TEG 6S trials include neonates or premature infants in the dataset. The youngest age group in current trials is 3 months to 18 years (NCT05874843).

Blood Collection Method

All trials use citrated blood (3.2% citric acid) and require reactivation before analysis. No small-volume protocols for neonates identified.

Neonatal Applications

Potential neonatal concerns (tiny blood volumes, different coagulation values) not addressed in any identified trials or publications.

FDA Clearance Status

TEG 6S received FDA 510(k) clearance in 2019 (K183160) with an updated cartridge in 2024. No specific neonatal clearance documented.

Neonatal Research Gap Analysis

Current Limitations

  • No trials include neonates (<28 days) or premature infants
  • Youngest cohort: 3 months to 18 years (NCT05874843)
  • Blood volume constraints of neonates not addressed in any protocols
  • No specific neonatal reference ranges available for TEG 6S parameters
  • Citrated blood draw procedures not validated for very small volume collections

Clinical Implications

  • Premature and newborn infants have distinct coagulation profiles compared to older children and adults
  • Standard blood collection volumes may be excessive for neonates with limited blood volume
  • Interpretation of TEG 6S results in neonates would require specific reference ranges
  • Risk/benefit ratio of TEG 6S testing in neonates has not been formally assessed

Research Opportunities

  • Validation study of TEG 6S in neonatal populations with age-appropriate reference ranges
  • Development of micro-sampling techniques compatible with TEG 6S cartridges
  • Comparison of citrated vs. non-citrated samples in neonatal blood
  • Assessment of minimal blood volume requirements for valid results
